I alway start with the travel aggregators. My favorite is SkyScanner at the moment, but have also had good luck with Kayak. From there, you can add your starting location and destination, and they will search a lot of the major airlines, as well as other OTAs (online travel agencies). Usually just doing that will get you 90% of the way to the cheapest price. On top of that, I would search for the budget airlines in the location that you’re flying. Sometimes their prices and routes don’t appear on the travel aggregators because they don’t want to give up any commissions (which keeps their prices lower). Those budget airlines vary all around the world, so do some research about your location and then get to it. This might get you another 7% to the cheapest price. Finally, you can see if there are any price movement predictions. Kayak has a good tool that tells you the probability of the price rising or decreasing in the next 7 days. These price prediction services come and go because there’s a lot of interesting data science going on in the background, which is valuable. If the probabilities work out in your favor, then you might be able to get to that extra 3%, on average. And don’t forget about the tradeoffs: Are you really trying to get the cheapest price? If so, will you accept a flight with 4 layovers that takes 59 hours? Maybe not, but perhaps a single layover is acceptable, or maybe 2 because you’ll have the perfect book to read all day long. Or do you really care about travel times? Would you be willing to fly from 1:30AM to 5AM to get the cheapest flight? Or would you prefer to fly during reasonable daylight hours? I’ve seen all of these scenarios recently. I tend to look for the right combination of cheapness, direct-ness, and during reasonable hours.

Forget about it.   There will ALWAYS be someone who has paid less than you.   You need to concentrate on value not price.   Is it worth $10 to take two flights instead of a non stop?   If you fly on an airline that offers 28" pitch would you pay $20 to fly on one with 31" pitch (I would but then I'm 6ft 2in).   Do you have to go to an airport that costs $10 more to get to just to save $5 on the fare? There are all sorts of theories about when to book.   People claim you need to do it on Tuesday, others say book months in advance while a different group will say wait until the last minute.    You're up against an airline revenue department.   These guys really know their market.   They price based on data you might never consider.   For instance, suppose you live somewhere with a large ethnic population.   You want to go to Washington DC.   There's nothing special on in Washington, it's late January who wants to go to Washington?   Ah, but your ethnic neighbours want to go home because there's a religious festival you've never heard of they want to attend.   The only flight to their home country goes from Washington.   If the revenue manager knows that will he try and sell tickets for higher amounts to people heading to the festival via Washington or a peanut fare to you just to get to Washington?   It's a real nighmare, festivals, public holidays, conventions, sports events, stadium concerts and who knows what else are fed into the revenue mix. There are a few guides.   Airlines apply seasons to some international routes so find out about the seasons and pick the cheaper season.  Midweek travel is usually cheaper - on the Atlantic, for example, Tuesday and Wednesday quite often have the lowest loads so they're trying to drum up business.

I would re-command these tips for cheap flight tickets #Befriend budget airlines Budget airlines offer significantly cheaper tickets than their full-service counterparts. It should be obvious, but this comes with compromises such as less leg room and no “free” food/drink on-board (which by the way, is normally covered in your higher-priced ticket with full-service airlines).Below is a comprehensive list of budget airlines around the globe. Red indicates true budget airlines while blue implies the cheapest companies available where budget airlines don’t exist or aren’t plentiful. But First… A NOTE ON BOOKING BUDGET AIRLINES. Always read the fine print and do the following: Check where the airport location is (some budget airlines fly to airports further out of town). Ensure you’ve booked & paid for your luggage allowance. Adhere to restrictions on weight, height, and # of bags allowed. Some airlines (e.g. Ryanair) will charge hefty fee if you’re over. Remember, paying only for the exact luggage space/weight you need is how budget airlines keep their prices lower than traditional airlines! Read the fine print. The best example is that Ryanair WILL CHARGE A FEE if you do not print your own ticket or adhere to their strict luggage weight and dimensions. A warning of this fee is clearly stated in all capital letters in the first sentence of your e-confirmation. In a nutshell, always read and follow instructions! Remember, if you want to book the cheapest flight possible (not service-of-the-year-award-winner), be adaptable, do your research, and know the budget airline’s requirements & restrictions. Use Twitter, Facebook or regularly check budget airline web pages to keep you in touch with specials before they sell out. Air Asia, Jetstar, Tiger Air and Ryanair are especially good at having regular deals. #Book connecting flights yourself for less If you’re flying somewhere that involves a transfer, say from Canada to Australia which typically involves Canada to LA, then LA to Australia, consider that it may be cheaper to book these two legs separately on your own by adding another destination to your trip. It should go without saying that in doing this, you should not book tight layovers. I repeat: do not book layovers that are hours apart! This approach is for those who want to create an additional destination of a few days or more, before catching their next flight. The one exception is when booking with Kiwi.com | Find Cheap Flights & Discover New Destinations, who offer their own guarantee on making connecting flights even when not with the same partner airlines. First, do your research: are there budget airlines unique to the country you’re flying out of and where you’re headed to? Booking with a budget Australian airline (Jetstar) from Sydney to Honolulu, then an American one from Honolulu to Montreal saved us over $400 each when flying back from Australia to Canada earlier this year. This allowed us to create a thrifty five-day stopover in Hawaii on our way back, which was less exhausting and a lot cheaper! Kiwi.com | Find Cheap Flights & Discover New Destinations and AirWander are both great search engine for revealing cheaper routes like this that involve multiple airlines.

Smart ways to book cheap flight tickets. 1. Be flexible with travel dates You might have come across websites claiming that booking flight tickets on a Tuesday or travelling on a weekday would save you big bucks. But that’s not always true. So, we suggest, you check out the prices for the entire month. This way, you will get a clear picture of days that are cheaper for your destination. Where do you check the month prices? Browse through Google Flights, Skyscanner or Hopper. Either try it on the website or the mobileapp. What you have to do is simply feed in your departure and arrival cities. First, check for one-way fare. Click depart, do not enter a date, instead select the whole month. Then, click - search flights and you’ll get to know the date which offers the lowest fare. Now, follow the above steps for your return flight to get the cheapest fare. If you’re booking on the mobile app, you can view the price chart and book accordingly.2. Go for local airlinesMost of the search engines do not show local airlines. This happens mostly in case of remote places or less popular routes. If you’re flying to any such destination, we suggest, you search on Google for the local airlines. Then, visit the local airlines website and check for any offers or deals. This will definitely help you, book your flights at a lower fare.3. Use incognito when searching for flightsHave you noticed that, each time you search for your flights, the fare prices increase in your web browser? Well, that happens due to the cookies in your browser. The website increases the fare after repeated search, so that you book your flight, then and there. You begin to anticipate that prices will increase further. Hence, we advise - when you search for flights, do it in the incognito mode. Each time, open a new incognito window before you begin your search. This way, your previous searches won’t be stored, and you won’t see raised flight fares. Other alternatives include browsing from a different laptop/computer or clearing your cookies to get lower fares.4. If possible, make payment in a currency cheaper than the Indian rupeeMany travellers use this option to get cheaper fares. Most of the airlines ask you to make payment in the currency of the country you’re travelling from. The next time, when you’re booking your flight tickets, check if you can pay in any other currency which is cheaper than your own. A word of caution here - If you’re making the payment through your credit card, your credit card shouldn’t levy foreign-transaction fees. Then only, go ahead and book your tickets.5. Book your flights well in advance If your travel dates and destination both are fixed, we suggest - you book your flight tickets right away. The reason being - as your departure date approaches, the airline fares will only increase, exceptions are very few here. By booking your flight tickets well in advance, you can save big and utilise the savings for other enjoyable experiences.6. Set fare alerts When you visit airlines pages, do remember to set fare alerts. By doing this, you will get to know about the special offers, before they sell out and enable you to book cheap flight tickets. You can also follow pages of budget airlines like GoAir, Air Asia, Jetstar, Indigo and SpiceJet on Facebook and Twitter to learn about various deals and offers.7. Identify the cheapest place to travelIf you're itching to travel but don’t have any specific destination in mind, then this trick is for you. You can use search engines to find out which places offer cheap flight fares, then accordingly freeze your holiday destination as per your interest. Thinking which website to visit? Well, you can try Skyscanner. Simply, enter your departure city and hit the search for cheap flights to anywhere in the world. Then, select the destination of your choice from the list of cheapest places to fly and book your tickets. This smart move will help you travel to exotic places and satiate the wanderlust in you.8. Make use of flight pointsIf you’re a frequent flyer of a particular airline, you certainly earn air miles points as part of the loyalty program offered by the airline. For instance, Jet Airways offers JetPrivilege Miles wherein, depending on your miles, you can use them to get cheaper flight fares. You can make most of these points while travelling to domestic destinations. However, if you earn more points, you can also qualify for an award flight to your favourite destination.9. Compare and buy flight tickets Most of the travel search engines have inflated flight fares as part of taking a cut from the airlines. So, we suggest you try search engines like Google Flights, Skyscanner, JetRadar and Airfarewatchdog where you can get lower flight fares. What you have to do is try each one of them and compare the air fares for different airlines. Go ahead and book your flight tickets which offers the cheapest air fares.10. When booking connecting flights, do it yourselfMany a time, we have connecting flights and have to change from one plane to another on the way to our final destination. For such journeys, we suggest you visit the AirWander website. This search engine will offer you cheaper routes with multiple airlines options and save you more money.11. Book on the cheapest day If you’re a night owl, then this trick is for you. If you aren’t, then it’s time to be one! You ask: Is it applicable thorough out the week? Unfortunately, no. According to research, if you book your flight tickets at midnight - Monday through Wednesday, you get cheaper air fares.

You get what you pay for. If you think you've found a great deal then fine, but make sure that It's an airline that you are prepared to use. Look here for safety ratings Airline & Safety Ratings - Airline RatingsIf you want to check a bag make sure that it is included in the fare. Some low cost airlines really sting you there. Add that to the ticket cost.Meals on board. 25 euros for a tray meal is not unusual. Sure, you can take sandwiches but after ten hours or so they will be looking a bit sad. Not a problem for a short flight.You might want a drink. Will it be included in the fare? No? That's another addition.Seat selection. Ticket prices depend on a number of factors. The first and the foremost is the Time. Earlier you buy a ticket the cheaper it would be. The second factor is Competition. In a highly competitive market airlines have quite a bit of unsold capacity, which they tend to sell at a marginal cost. The third factor is the Season. Airline business is afflicted with some low seasons over a period of an year. In low seasons airlines’ capacity far exceeds the demand in market, compelling airlines to sell some of the seats dirt cheap, provided you buy them in advance. Additionally, Start up airlines generally sell almost all their inventory below cost to capture the market share. One may also take advantage of that if such an opportunity is available.
